SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional bloating. He attributes these symptoms to the change in seasons and recent home construction projects. The patient has been experiencing these symptoms for approximately five weeks. He denies fever, chills, and significant shortness of breath. He reports a slight cough and occasional chest cramps that resolve within an hour. The patient has been monitoring his blood pressure at home and reports it has been well-controlled. His diet has been off due to recent kitchen renovations, leading to eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. No fever or chills.
• Cardiovascular: Occasional chest cramps. No significant shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Slight cough. No significant shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Appears well.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at lung bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor daily weight and report any significant weight gain or worsening shortness of breath. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure appears well-controlled at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a rhinoplasty. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is present with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation in the lower extremity. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid, but everything else appears to be lined up properly.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her into a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin, 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food for a 2-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning, and he felt a pop in his lower back. He had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved, and it has been stiff ever since. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat, but they did not provide significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. No other joint pain.
• Neurological: Denies numbness. Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Back X-ray, obtained in the office today, is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoiding strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening and pain management.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with metformin and dietary modifications, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are slightly elevated, and the patient is currently on lisinopril 10 mg daily.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, follow-up of depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He is managing his depression well with medication.

Regarding his hypertension, he is taking Norvasc regularly during the weekdays but admits to occasionally forgetting on weekends. His blood pressure in the office today is 120/80 mmHg.

The patient had a lobectomy a couple of years ago. He reports occasional shortness of breath during exertion, especially when running in humid conditions. He runs 4-5 miles daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, reports occasional pounding in the chest during exertion.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle aches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression:
   • Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to continue current management strategies.

2. Prior Lobectomy:
   • Medical Reasoning: No concerning findings on chest X-ray, patient exercising regularly.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

3. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure controlled in the office, patient taking Norvasc regularly.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to maintain medication compliance, including on weekends.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent backward while skiing over moguls.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and normal alignment.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up if the pain does not improve within a week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents as a new patient referred by Diane Nelson for long-standing iron deficiency anemia. The patient reports being anemic since the age of 13. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. The patient also reports increased anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with normal results.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency anemia.
Hysterectomy in 1996.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Alcohol consumption: once or twice a year.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets, twice daily.
Over-the-counter Vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
Heart and lungs: normal.

Abdominal
No tenderness upon palpation.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Upper endoscopy and colonoscopy: Schedule the patient for these procedures to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.

2. Hematologist referral: Send a referral to Dr. Flores, a hematologist, for further evaluation and management.

3. Iron supplementation: Instruct the patient to continue taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice (for Vitamin C) for the next 8-12 weeks. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate levels after this period.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule appointments for upper endoscopy, colonoscopy, and hematologist consultation. Follow bowel prep instructions provided. Call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. He has no prior history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Pertinent labs and radiology studies were reviewed, including a pituitary hormone profile demonstrating a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. No other abnormalities were noted.

During the consultation, the patient reported headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache, with a severity of 6/10. The headaches have been gradually worsening over the past three months and tend to be worse in the morning. The patient also mentioned bumping into door frames recently. No other symptoms were reported.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer.
Marital status: Married for 25 years.
Alcohol, tobacco, and drug use: None.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

EXAMINATION

The patient is alert and oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma.

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa due to symptomatic clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
2. Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
3. Schedule surgery with the transsphenoidal approach, and discuss the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53 y.o. female who presents today for a new patient evaluation due to a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, which resolved after four days. She has not had any recurrence of these symptoms since then. The patient reports that her chest pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and felt like a sharp pain. The pain was worse with eating. She also had difficulty swallowing during this time.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Uterine fibroids.
Anemia.
Esophagitis (suspected).

Surgical
Gallbladder removal.

SOCIAL HISTORY

No information provided.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of GI problems.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

No information provided.

ALLERGIES

No information provided.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Negative for abdominal pain, weight loss, weight gain, headaches, bone pain, urinary symptoms, blood in the stools.
Positive for chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, which has since resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020, with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal causes, and anxiety. The patient experienced a stressful job transition around the time of her symptoms, which may have contributed to her condition.

PLAN

1. The patient will self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
2. If symptoms recur, the patient may be scheduled for an EGD to further evaluate her esophagus and stomach.
3. Follow up with the patient as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney evaluation for Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. The patient has had issues with feeding, temperature regulation, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a GI doctor, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's geneticist mentioned potential kidney issues associated with her syndrome, prompting the evaluation today.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Premature birth.
Feeding difficulties.
Developmental delays.

FAMILY HISTORY

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Perform kidney ultrasound today to evaluate for any abnormalities.
2. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed. If abnormalities are found, schedule a follow-up appointment at the Town Center location to discuss next steps and future management.
3. Continue with current therapies and specialist appointments as needed.

INSTRUCTIONS

Complete kidney ultrasound today. Await results and follow-up instructions from the clinic.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms. She reports that her right wrist started to hurt immediately and became swollen. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided some relief but not enough. The patient denies any previous injuries to this arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no thyromegaly, no adenopathy.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
MSK: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a fist. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist taken in office today reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient with a brace and surgery. The patient will be given a brace today and scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be placed in a brace for six weeks and will attend physical therapy three times a week. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess the patient's progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the prescribed treatment plan and attend all physical therapy sessions. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, on 20 mg Lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation on the medial aspect. Edema and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slipping and falling, causing knee pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and inflammation. Provide a knee brace for support. Advise icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage elevation and rest for the affected knee.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg Lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue 20 mg Lisinopril. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary counseling to help manage hypertension.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and suspects it might be related. The patient states he is very active and has experienced occasional aches and pains before that usually resolve with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant and worsens when pressure is applied. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that her left knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to nearly fall. The pain is located internally in the knee and comes and goes quickly. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any medications for pain, as it does not last long. The patient is concerned about her upcoming trip, which will involve a lot of walking and line dancing, and is unsure if she will be able to participate due to her knee issues.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the surrounding muscles.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and make any necessary adjustments to the Metformin dosage.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer, currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family members and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat. Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting. Reports decreased appetite.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy noted.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs appreciated.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles noted bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the left chest, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema noted.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide and receiving radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen and radiation dose. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor response and potential for surgical intervention.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and bilateral crackles on lung exam are likely due to radiation-induced inflammation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Sore throat and painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat is likely due to radiation-induced inflammation in the esophagus.
- Medical Treatment: In addition to prednisone, prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow to be used four times a day to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime that tend to linger for a long time. No recent history of abdominal infections or diarrhea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes, recently started on Metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works at a family-owned donut shop.

TRAVEL HISTORY

Recent international travel to Zambia.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness.

VITALS

All vitals within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LABORATORY RESULTS

Consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work is consistent with IgA deficiency, a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not seem to have frequent infections that would warrant concern.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Explained the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check for other immunodeficiencies.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing right elbow pain for approximately 4 days. He reports that the pain is localized to the inside of his elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is described as a 6/10 in severity and is affecting his sleep and daily activities. The patient has been taking ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has recently been engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we had a discussion in regards to his current symptoms. The plan is to have the patient rest his elbow and wear a sling while awake. He is advised to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is instructed to hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to evaluate his progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during physical activity.
Genitourinary: Denies any issues.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to make dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Advised to monitor weight daily and contact the doctor if a 3-pound weight gain occurs in 2 days.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed dietary modifications.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes in waves. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father). A CT scan was ordered by his primary care physician, which revealed a kidney stone.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone (acute nephrolithiasis).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. The patient may continue to take Tylenol as well.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain his urine and monitor for stone passage.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to check on the patient's progress. If symptoms have not improved, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The patient describes the ulcer as initially having a stinging sensation, but now experiences throbbing pain. He also reports cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak along the inside portion of his calf muscle. The patient has been on antibiotics for 6 days and has a few days left in the course. He has experienced fever and chills, as well as a recent increase in coughing and difficulty catching his breath.

The patient's blood sugar has been trending higher in the past few weeks, with some readings in the 300-400 range and one spike at 500-600. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail. He wears diabetic shoes and inserts, which he changes every 3-4 months.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever and chills.
Respiratory: Reports increased coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports cramping in calf muscle.
Skin: Reports non-healing right foot ulcer.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes
3. Diabetic neuropathy

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's calf closely.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Recommend the patient to follow up with their endocrinologist for diabetes management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in the yard.

FAMILY HISTORY

Patient reports typical arthritic pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and erythema.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Not reported
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Examination: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.

Skin
- Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with tick bite on right knee and bull's-eye rash.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks. Send Lyme titer and Western blot tests to confirm diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently taking lisinopril.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day. Order lipid panel to monitor cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of diabetes and is currently taking metformin.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day. Order hemoglobin A1C to monitor long-term blood sugar levels. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.
